bestBHT.bht: The father's faith is tested by the Lord, who inquires about the disciples' failure and the severity of his son's condition. The father draws hope from what he had heard about Christ, though he is dispirited by their inadequacy and the aggravation of his son's malady. It is important to recognize that this affliction is not a result of the child's sins, but a hidden judgment from God meant to test their obedience. The prolonged and stubborn nature of the disorder showcases the divine power and goodness at work, revealing the impact of original sin.

Henry Alford: 21.] The Lord takes occasion to enquire thus of the father, to bring in the trial of his faith.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: half dispirited by the failure of the disciples
aggravated virulence of the malady itself in presence of their Master
encouraged too by what he had heard of Christ
John Calvin: From a child. Hence we infer that this punishment was not inflicted on account of the sins of the individual, but was a secret judgment of God.
True indeed, even infants... are not innocent in the sight of God, or free from guilt; but God’s chastisements have sometimes hidden causes, and are intended to try our obedience.
We do not render to God the honor which is due to Him, unless with reverence and modesty we adore His justice, when it is concealed from us.
Philip Schaff: Mark 9:21. And he asked his father. To bring out his faith.
John Gill: the length and stubbornness of his disorder might be known, and so the cure the more remarkable, and appear the more expressive of his divine power and goodness
it was not for any actual sin that he had committed, that this sore affliction came upon him
must be tainted with original sin, which is the source and spring of all afflictions, calamities and judgments

bhtAttempts.bht: The father's faith is tested by the Lord in this verse, and his weariness from the disciples' failed attempts and the severity of his son's condition is mixed with hope from what he had heard about Christ. It is noteworthy that this affliction was not punishment for the child's sins, but rather a hidden judgment of God to try their obedience. Even infants, though not innocent in the sight of God, can be subject to His secret judgments. Through this trial, the length and stubbornness of the disorder serves to highlight the remarkable nature of the cure and the divine power and goodness at work. It is a reminder that all afflictions and hardships can ultimately be traced back to the presence of original sin.
